8.82.text:
[ Applause ]
>>Clare Balding: I'm slightly worried about

9.82.text:
you because having watched Sir Ranulph Fiennes's
presentation I think you are sitting there

17.25.text:
Just looking at Ranulph's hands is that I
always thought a few short tendons and a few

24.59.text:
blisters, but they're in very good condition
compared to his.

29.44.text: You clearly haven't tried hard enough.

31.52.text:
[ Laughter ]
>>Clare Balding: There is a shot there of

35.73.text:
your family, and actually I was quite pleased
watching.

38.49.text:
A lot of shots in that film I was with the
cameraman who took them and we got into the

42.65.text:
family enclosure when we weren't meant to
and certainly had a camera running when we

46.51.text:
weren't meant to but it meant we could see
your family's reaction to your achievements.

51.40.text:
How much did you actually spend time with
your family and, indeed, think about them

62.76.text:
In the sort of 12 months leading up to games,
we had been away on training camps a lot.

66.39.text:
So you would be at home for two or three weeks,
you'd be away for two or three weeks.

69.95.text: And that was sort of the routine.

72.27.text:
And having young children by the end of it,
my eldest was nine, my youngest was two at

77.14.text:
the time, is that routine is a great thing
for family life.

82.93.text:
And so when you're at home, you train very
early in the morning, finish by about 1:00

87.99.text:
on the shortest days and 3:00 on the longer
days.

91.28.text:
So I could actually pick up the children from
school.

93.83.text:
That's great for the two or three weeks that
you're at home but then you're away and that's

96.93.text:
all left to your partner who has got to sort
of run family life from that point of view.

101.79.text:
And I think that made it difficult from that
point of view.

104.59.text:
My wife was an Olympic athlete in her own
right so she knew what she was marrying into

109.10.text:
at that time, but a big change in my life
was when children came along because what

115.30.text:
I used to do for fun, messing about in boats
on the river and lakes around the world, is

120.16.text: I had to change from that point of view.

121.61.text:
I had to try to become a little bit more financially
solvent from that point of view, which wasn't

128.05.text:
>>Clare Balding: It is worth making the point
that throughout your Olympic career, U.K.

132.29.text:
lottery funding came in and at least you were
able to finance your sport, but you were never

141.18.text: It's not a sport you go into to make money.

142.70.text:
>>Steve Redgrave: Lottery grants came for
British athletes after the Atlanta games,

148.63.text:
and Matthew and I picked up our first sponsorship
just before that that put us out of the regime

155.57.text:
So that we weren't really that closely affected
with the lottery money.

159.20.text:
It helped for the team on training camps and
from that point of view, but we didn't get

163.29.text: a direct grant from that, unfortunately.

164.98.text:
>>Clare Balding: Do you think were you born
slightly different and special or did you

171.07.text:
Did you know that you had the ability to push
your body beyond the limits of the rest of

177.33.text: us, if I can say that?

181.59.text:
I was heavily dyslexic, I still am, and school
life was pretty tough from that point of view,

186.75.text:
struggling to read and write, of being put
into the sort of lower sets of all the classes

193.87.text: apart from sport, which I was reasonable at.

196.49.text:
But I went to a small comprehensive school,
and the head of the English department had

202.70.text:
One was rugby and the other was rowing, and
he asked me if I would like to try the sport

207.01.text: of rowing at the age of 13, nearly 14.

210.29.text:
And to me, great, once a week, games lessons,
I could leave school, go out on the river.

216.78.text:
Unfortunately, after two or three weeks I
started going down every day after school,

221.46.text: and it sort of became my life in some ways.

224.78.text:
And at a very young age is that, from rowing
at Marlow Rowing Club, it's not that far away

229.45.text:
from here, about a half an hour's drive from
where we are now, where I live, is that there

234.16.text: were people that were on the national team.

235.74.text:
We had three coaches at Marlow Rowing Club
that were part of national team, and they

239.85.text: were saying you could be world champion.

242.10.text: You are capable of one day being a world champion.

244.44.text: And I said that sounds great.

245.94.text: Yeah, that gives me a little focus.

248.24.text:
It was one of the best things that happened
to me but also one of the worst things that

252.03.text:
happened because I believed one day I was
going to be world champion.

255.68.text:
And I thought, well, why not world champion,
why not Olympic champion.

259.11.text:
So I started setting my goals from that point
of view.

261.22.text:
But I honestly believed that one day it was
going to happen.

264.02.text:
All I didn't know is which year it was going
to be.

266.38.text: I felt my name was engraved on the trophy.

269.12.text:
It was just going to decide what year it was
going to be.

271.61.text:
So you sort of bide your time, you follow
the coaching process of what you are asked

276.08.text:
We didn't have any history, recent history
of performance at that time, so you are following

282.16.text: a path of a team that hasn't been succeeding.

286.68.text:
And I went to one world championships and
performed really badly and that was the best

290.56.text:
thing that ever happened to me because I felt,
well, other people think I am capable of doing

294.42.text:
this, I think I am capable of doing this,
why isn't it happening?

297.17.text:
And we reevaluated the whole process and looked
at it and decided that we weren't really trying

302.32.text:
hard enough, we weren't taking it professionally
enough.

305.62.text: And so sort of changed the attitude.

307.96.text: And within nine months became Olympic champion.

309.86.text:
>>Clare Balding: Can you remember in terms
of breaking down what it was that you did

314.82.text:
You clearly had the confidence and self-belief,
and you've talked about that.

320.43.text:
What do you -- do you rip up the whole book,
or do you just take certain things and say,

324.54.text: "Right, I need to change this approach?"

326.02.text:
>>Steve Redgrave: When you're trying to get
to the top, it's easier to follow a path of

333.51.text: So there are books out there.

334.75.text:
There are stories of how to be able to get
there.

338.22.text:
So actually getting there is relatively easy,
even though it is still extremely hard.

343.40.text:
Once you get there to try and get to a new
level that no one's ever performed at before,

348.89.text:
that's where the book has to be ripped up
and start again.

352.15.text:
I suppose the process that I started to develop
was we all know about personal bests and you

359.03.text: set yourself targets to get to.

361.98.text: Not everyone can be Olympic champion.

363.40.text: Not everyone can be the best in their field.

365.76.text: But we can all be better than we are.

367.84.text:
We can all improve and look for our own personal
bests.

370.95.text:
I think what really sums this up to me -- it
is a very old story, but a guy called John

374.98.text: Naber, who is an American swimmer.

376.89.text: He competed at the Munich Games 1972.

380.83.text:
He was part of the American relay team in
the swimming competition and helped that team

385.62.text:
qualify for the final but didn't swim in the
final himself.

388.81.text:
He came out of those games, he thought, "How
can I get to the next level?

393.62.text: I want to win that gold medal.

394.81.text:
I want to be part of that relay team in '76
in Montreal."

400.95.text:
So what he did is he actually looked back
through the history books and saw a steady

404.36.text:
improvement and almost could predict a time
that he felt he had to do to win that gold

409.29.text:
medal in four years' time in the individual
event, not just the team event.

414.88.text: He predicted a time of 55.5 seconds.

416.74.text: That's what he had to do.

417.74.text: His discipline was the 100 meters backstroke.

419.85.text:
The problem was his personal best at that
time was 59.5 seconds.

423.67.text:
He had to go four seconds quicker over 100
meters swimming on his back.

427.95.text: He thought, "I can't do that, it is impossible."

430.89.text:
By setting himself these targets sort of blew
himself away that he couldn't achieve it.

436.02.text:
But then he started thinking a little bit
more laterally about it, thinking, I don't

439.89.text:
have to swim that time today, tomorrow, this
year.

442.05.text: I have got four years to do it.

444.01.text: That's a second improvement in every year.

446.51.text: He trained for ten months every year.

448.19.text:
1/10th of a second improvement in a month's
training.

452.91.text: That's 1/300th improvement in a day's training.

456.53.text:
He used to train for four hours a day every
day during that training period.

461.68.text: So that's 1/1200th second of an improvement.

465.00.text: It takes an eye to blink 5/1200ths of a second.

467.94.text:
He is looking for 1/5 of a eye blink improvement
in an hour's training.

473.26.text:
There is something about defining that will
make you go a little bit quicker.

476.92.text:
The difficult thing is you go do that every
hour of every day of every month of every

482.84.text:
Obviously, the moral of the story is he did
get to the games.

485.37.text:
He was part of the relay team that took the
gold medal and swum in that final.

489.37.text:
And he made the final of the individual event
where he was racing two-time Olympic champion,

493.96.text:
world record holder and that sort of process
and took the gold medal in a time of 59.49

503.06.text:
So what seemed to be impossible, he broke
it down, looked at it very laterally in a

507.65.text:
different way from more ways of looking at
it.

509.99.text:
In some ways, that's what you have got to
do.

512.88.text: Those targets are great to be able to do that.

515.18.text:
When I retired, I then started raising money
for charity.

519.99.text:
And I set up my own charitable trust to try
to raise 5 million pounds in five years.

524.27.text: I thought -- I remember that story.

525.95.text: I'm going to break it all down.

527.56.text:
Breaking it down to 20,000 pounds a week every
week for five years having two weeks off each

532.52.text: year, it is not going to happen.

533.90.text:
We actually looked at it from a different
point of view, focused on big occasions to

537.56.text: try to raise a lot of money.

539.52.text:
Really what you have to do is to look at the
tasks you have, look at the way your process

543.65.text:
of doing it, and then maybe turn it on its
head and look at it in different ways.

547.62.text:
To get to the next level, you just go look
at all the tools you can offer in that direction

553.49.text:
>>Clare Balding: Your body was very much your
friend and certainly through the early part

556.57.text: of your career until you got diabetes.

559.82.text:
What happened then and how did you have to
change your nutritional plan?

563.43.text:
And, actually, did you have to reassess whether
you were still capable of doing what you wanted

568.11.text:
>>Steve Redgrave: Once I was diagnosed, I
thought it was my international career over.

570.96.text: That was three years before my last Olympics.

573.50.text:
I had a grandfather that had diabetes in his
late 60s, early 70s and didn't survive much

579.94.text: I knew it was a pretty serious condition.

581.37.text:
So I knew that had to be monitored and being
an Olympic top athlete is not going to happen.

587.50.text:
So I went to the consultation stage, that
I was expecting my consultant is now going

592.88.text: to tell me I can't do what I was doing.

595.05.text: I was with him for three hours.

596.56.text:
At the end of it, he said, Well, I don't see
any reason why you can't achieve your dreams

601.46.text:
I thought, if he thinks I can do it, I would
give it my best shot.

604.64.text: He did say it was going to be hard.

606.82.text:
He didn't tell me that he didn't have a clue
of how we were going to go about it and what

611.38.text:
He scoured the Internet in a few hours before
I came and saw him.

617.89.text:
So his vision, it wasn't until after we achieved
what we did he told me the reality that he

623.39.text:
didn't have a clue of how we were going to
do it.

625.20.text:
I suppose it was his attitude that I felt
that diabetes had to live with me, not me

630.44.text:
That was a quite good way of taking on the
challenge in some ways.
